1. The invention relates to an improved identification card containing an internal antenna and integrated circuit chip laminated between two protective, non-rigid layers onto which artwork may be printed, which are then laminated between two rigid outer layers. The card is designed to protect the electronic components from damage and is more durable than prior art cards. The invention provides a low-cost and easily constructed identification card.

2. The card is prepared by pre-shrinking a core layer, printing alkyd resin spids and antennae onto the core layer, and attaching an IC chip to the antennae. The core layer is then bonded to a bottom sheet with an adhesive layer, and two polymer layers are affixed to the bonded core layer and bottom sheet. The polymer layers provide mechanical strength to the image-receiving layer and hence to the image(s) in the finished document.

3. The identification card may have one or two image-receiving layers, and one or more second indicia intended for human reading may be printed on the image-receiving layer on the front side, and one or more additional second indicia intended for machine reading may be printed on the image-receiving layer on the back side. A protective layer is affixed over at least the portion of the or each image-receiving layer carrying the second indicia to protect the image-receiving layer from damage. The protective layer may include security features such as low cohesivity polymeric layer, optically variable ink, or image printed in an ink which is readable in the infra-red or ultraviolet.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to the implementation of a memory, specifically a queue, particularly a FIFO-type queue, in a functional memory environment.
2. In a traditional overwrite memory environment, a FIFO queue is typically implemented using a double-ended list, but this approach is inefficient in a functional memory environment.
3. The invention proposes a novel way of establishing a queue using a tree-shaped structure, where nodes have a maximum size and additions and deletions are directed to specific nodes in the tree.
4. The tree-shaped structure is maintained in a way that ensures all leaf nodes are at the same level, and all internal nodes are full except for those on the edges of the tree.
5. The invention allows for efficient updates to the queue, with a time and space complexity that is logarithmically dependent on the length of the queue.
6. The node to be updated is easily accessible by following the edge of the tree until a leaf node is found.
7. A preferred embodiment of the invention includes a header node with three elements, which points to the end and beginning of the queue, and the middle part of the queue.
8. The header node allows for faster and more space-efficient updates, and also enables the queue to be inverted in constant time and space.
9. The invention can be used to implement a double-ended queue, allowing for additions to the beginning and deletions from the end of the queue.
10. The invention can be implemented in a memory arrangement with a header node, intermediate registers, and control logic, which maintains the queue and performs updates and deletions.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to electrically programmable read-only memory (EPROM) devices that can be manufactured using existing integrated circuit (IC) technologies, allowing for the integration of EPROM devices with other types of integrated circuits, such as DRAM or logic circuits, on the same wafer.
2. The EPROM devices can be programmed using hot carrier effects or other types of electrical stresses to alter the properties of transistors, and can be used in a variety of applications, including programmable redundancy circuits, embedded applications, and security applications.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a method of determining feedback gain for feedback control, which involves calculating correction amounts based on errors between designated and actual values. The method allows for easy and quick determination of the optimum value of feedback gain.

2. The method involves provisionally determining a feedback gain, executing feedback control, detecting an error, calculating an evaluation value, and repeating these steps with different feedback gain values to determine the one that provides a suitable evaluation value. The evaluation value is calculated based on the error and reflects the stability, accuracy, and response of the control.

3. In a first embodiment, the method is applied to the running control of an automatic guidance vehicle (AGV), where the feedback gains are determined for each section of a running course. The AGV is driven repeatedly in each section to obtain data, and the feedback gains are determined based on the data.

4. The evaluation functions used in the first embodiment include LR, Svv, and Asv, which are suited for evaluating the P, I, and D gains, respectively. These functions are calculated based on the error data obtained during the running of the AGV.

5. The optimum values of the P, I, and D gains are determined by controlling the gains such that the evaluation functions approach their ideal values. The gains can be determined by function interpolation or by setting a fixed range around the ideal value.

6. In a second embodiment, the feedback gains are determined while the AGV makes an excursion of the entire running course. The AGV is caused to run along the course, and the feedback gains are determined at each section of the course based on the data obtained.

7. The second embodiment allows for the determination of the feedback gains in a shorter time and is suitable for cases where the running course is long or the AGV runs at high speeds. The method can be modified to accommodate different types of feedback gains and control systems.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to zoom lenses with a high relative aperture and a high zoom ratio, while minimizing the physical size of the entire lens system. The zoom lens is designed for use in photographic cameras and video cameras, particularly those with a 2/3 inch image pickup tube or plate. The lens has a small F-number, a high zoom ratio, and a standard image angle at the wide angle end. The lens is designed to achieve high grade optical performance throughout the entire zooming range.

2. The zoom lens consists of five lens units, including a first lens unit of positive power, a second lens unit of negative power, a third lens unit of negative power, a fourth lens unit of positive power, and a fifth lens unit with an image forming function. The fourth lens unit has a bi-convex lens with a rear surface of strong curvature, and the fifth lens unit has a specific arrangement of lenses to correct aberrations. The lens units are designed to correct various aberrations, including spherical aberration, coma, and chromatic aberration. The lens is designed to achieve a high zoom ratio while minimizing the variation of aberrations with zooming.

3. The invention achieves a reduction of the physical length of the entire lens system while minimizing the variation of aberrations with zooming. The lens is designed to satisfy specific conditions, including the range of refracting power for the rear surface of the first lens in the fourth lens unit, the range of refractive power ratio for the second lens in the fifth lens unit, and the range of Abbe numbers of the media of the first and sixth lenses in the fifth lens unit. The lens is designed to correct longitudinal and lateral chromatic aberrations in good balance. The lens is designed to achieve a high zoom ratio while minimizing the physical length of the entire lens system.

4. The invention provides four numerical examples of specific zoom lenses that satisfy the conditions of the invention. The numerical examples demonstrate the achievement of a high zoom ratio, a high relative aperture, and a short total length of the entire lens system. The total length of the lens system is reduced to as short as L=9.13φA to 9.19φA. The invention achieves a great advance in reduction of the size of the zoom lens while preserving high grade optical performance.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a method and device for detecting elementary particles, such as protons, ions, electrons, neutrons, and photons, in a detector.
2. The method involves generating a charge pulse in the detector when a particle passes through, converting the pulse into an electric signal, and amplifying and processing the signal to detect individual particles or integrate multiple particles.
3. The device includes a detector, a first fast amplifier for amplifying individual signals, and a second slow amplifier for integrating multiple signals, with the option to switch between the two amplifiers based on the signal rate.
4. The detector is designed to tap the charge pulses on the low-voltage side, which prevents interference from high-voltage cables and enables the detection of small-size signals.
5. The method and device can be used to detect both individual particles and integrate multiple particles, without knowing in advance the expected signal rates.
6. The invention is particularly useful for detecting particles in particle accelerators, reactor installations, and diagnostic devices such as X-ray devices and CT scanners.
7. The detector material can be doped or coated with a converter material to enable the detection of uncharged particles, and materials with fast charge transport at room temperature, such as diamond, can be used for high-count rate applications.
8. The invention enables the detection of elementary particles with high accuracy and reliability, and has applications in various fields, including scientific research, medical technology, and electrical power engineering.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to an apparatus for automatically spin checking driven disc assemblies used in friction clutches, which ensures that the assemblies are manufactured to have a thickness within closely maintained tolerances and are not excessively warped or non-planar in shape. The apparatus operates automatically without manual involvement by an operator and generates an external indication to the operator of whether the driven disc assembly is good or bad.

2. The prior test fixture for spin checking driven disc assemblies was slow, inefficient, and required several manual operations, and it did not provide an external indication of whether the tested assembly was good or bad. The new apparatus aims to improve upon these limitations.

3. The apparatus includes an enclosure with a stationary ring and a movable ring, a torque motor, and an electronic sensor to measure the distance between the rings. The driven disc assembly is mounted on a splined hub between the two rings.

4. The movable ring is moved toward the stationary ring to frictionally engage the driven disc assembly, and the distance between the rings is measured by the electronic sensor. The torque motor is then energized to exert a predetermined torque on the driven disc assembly.

5. The movable ring is gradually moved away from the stationary ring to reduce the frictional force, and the driven disc assembly begins to rotate under the urging of the torque motor. The distance between the rings is measured again when the driven disc assembly starts to rotate.

6. The difference between the two distances is compared with a standard value to determine if the driven disc assembly is excessively warped. If the warpage is within specified tolerances, the apparatus indicates that the assembly is good.

7. The apparatus includes a control system with a microprocessor, optical encoder, and display to control the operation of the torque motor and servo motor, and to provide a visual indication of the status of the apparatus. The microprocessor executes a program to control the operation of the apparatus.

8. The program reads the signals from the control switches, position sensor, and optical encoder, and actuates the torque motor and servo motor accordingly. The program also compares the measured warpage with the standard value and generates an indication of whether the assembly is good or bad.

9. The apparatus provides an improved method for spin checking driven disc assemblies, which is faster, more efficient, and more accurate than the prior method, and it minimizes the chances of operator error. The apparatus can also be used for statistical process control by storing the measurements for each assembly tested.

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to the field of image processing, specifically face age-estimation, and provides a method and system for estimating the age of a person from a digital image of their face. The invention uses a contourlet appearance model (CAM) to extract features from the face image, which are then used to estimate the age. The CAM is a statistical model that combines shape and texture information to represent the face. The model is trained on a database of images of faces with known ages.

2. The CAM is used to extract feature vectors from the face image, which are then classified as either youth or adult using a support vector machine (SVM) classifier. The SVM classifier is trained on a database of feature vectors from images of faces with known ages. The classifier outputs a label indicating whether the face is that of a youth or an adult. The classification step is important because the aging process is different for youths and adults.

3. Once the face is classified as either youth or adult, an aging function is applied to the feature vector to estimate the age. The aging function is a mapping from the feature vector to an age, and is learned from the training data. There are two aging functions, one for youths and one for adults, which are learned separately. The aging functions are used to estimate the age of the face based on the feature vector.

4. The invention uses a contourlet transform to extract texture features from the face image, which are then used to estimate the age. The contourlet transform is a multiscale transform that extracts features at different scales and orientations. The features are then used to train the CAM and the aging functions. The contourlet transform is robust to noise and can extract features that are relevant to age estimation.

5. The invention uses a support vector regression (SVR) algorithm to learn the aging functions. The SVR algorithm is a type of machine learning algorithm that learns a mapping from input features to output values. In this case, the input features are the feature vectors extracted from the face image, and the output values are the ages. The SVR algorithm is trained on a database of feature vectors and corresponding ages.

6. The invention can be used in a variety of applications, including security systems, age verification systems, and demographic analysis. The system can be used to estimate the age of individuals in real-time, and can be integrated with other systems such as facial recognition systems. The system can also be used to analyze demographic trends and patterns in age distribution.

7. The invention

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a matrix display device for displaying two merged images, where one image has a higher definition than the other. The device preserves the definition of the higher-definition image. The invention makes it possible to implement algorithms that are facilitated and can be carried out by the controller of the matrix display. The controller produces display light intensity signals for each pixel of the matrix.

2. The matrix display device comprises a mosaic of identical arrangements of pixels, where each arrangement has a plurality of pixels. The pixels of each arrangement are dedicated to display either the first image or the second image. The first image and the second image are merged to form a single image on the display device. The invention can be applied to various types of display devices, including OLED, LED, and LCD.

3. The invention proposes that each pixel of an arrangement of pixels of the merged image be formed either via a light intensity signal associated with the first image or via a light intensity signal associated with the second image. The light intensity signals can be combined to form the merged image. The invention is particularly suited to cases where the second image is monochrome or two-color. The second image can be displayed on a definition corresponding to a quarter of the definition of the matrix of the display device.

4. The display of the merged image can be implemented via two operations: mapping the first image to the display device and mapping the second image to the display device. The mapping of the second image can consist of mapping the first color to a submatrix of pixels and mapping the second color to another submatrix of pixels. The invention can be applied to various types of images, including night vision images, infrared images, and X-ray images.

5. The invention also proposes means for reinforcing the contrast of the merged image. The means can correct the display of the first image by attenuating the light levels of the first image without attenuating the darker levels. The invention can be applied to various types of display devices, including those with a dedicated hardware architecture. The dedicated hardware architecture can offer an advantage in terms of lower consumption in operation.

6. Practical exemplary embodiments of the invention are described, including combining a first image originating from a night vision sensor with a second graphical image generated by a microcontroller or microcomputer. The invention can be applied to various types of images and display devices, and offers advantages in terms of preserving the definition of the higher-definition image and facilitating the implementation of algorithms. The invention can be used in various applications, including military, medical, and industrial applications

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a mobile identification transmitter for keyless activation of a security system in a motor vehicle, which has a housing with electronics and a communication means, and a payment element removably fastened in a receptacle of the housing. The payment element can be removed from the housing by the user if necessary, such as when bringing the vehicle to a repair shop or lending it to someone else.

2. The payment element can be brought into data communication with a payment system, and has a credit card function and/or debit card function, allowing for cashless payment transactions. The payment element can be designed with a microprocessor, storage device, and communication means to execute remote financial transactions.

3. The receptacle has contact elements that the payment element contacts and connects to in the normal state, and the closure protects the contact elements from the external environment in the secure state. The closure can be designed as a dummy plug that is fastened to a cable of the housing, ensuring a reliable hold in the receptacle.

4. The identification transmitter can have an energy storage device to supply the electronics and payment element with current, and a second energy storage device can be included as a redundancy. The energy storage device can be designed as a battery, accumulator, magnetic energy storage device, or capacitor.

5. The communication means of the payment element can have a range of less than 20 cm, and communicate with the payment system cryptographically, ensuring secure payment transactions. The communication means can work in a frequency range of approximately 13.56 MHz, achieving data transmission rates of more than 400 kBits per second.

<summary>

1. The imaging device, such as a xerographic machine, becomes inactive when not in use and is often put into a "sleep mode" to save energy. When the device "wakes up" from the sleep mode, it starts warming up and performs imaging operations with toner.

2. The toner used in the imaging device is charged with a tribo-electro-static charge, and a toner concentration (TC) sensor measures the concentration of the toner in the developer by detecting the tribo charge. The TC sensor output is used to adjust the supply of toner to increase the concentration when it is low.

3. If the imaging device is inactive for a long period, the tribo charge of the toner may decrease, affecting the image quality in an imaging operation. The image quality may become inconsistent and darker than the image quality during normal or continual use.

4. The disclosed embodiments address the issue of tribo charge decrease by determining one or more periods of inactivity of the imaging device and charging the toner to a predetermined level based on the determined period of inactivity. This ensures that the tribo charge of the toner is returned to the level of normal operation after recovering from inactivity.

5. The imaging device includes a developer station that advances development material into contact with the electrostatic latent image, and a TC sensor that monitors the concentration of the mixed toner and developer by detecting the tribo charge of the toner. If the concentration of the toner is low, a signal is sent to a controller to increase the supply of toner.

6. The controller includes an inactivity determining section that determines the activity of the machine, a predicting section that predicts the next user usage, and a measuring section that measures the TC sensor level. The controller also includes a calculating section that calculates the decay of the tribo charge of the toner based on the difference between two sensor levels.

7. The inactivity determining section determines the user usage pattern, and the predicting section predicts the next user usage based on the user pattern. The measuring section measures the sensor level at various times during the usage of the machine, including during the cycle-in and cycle-out of the machine.

8. The calculating section calculates the decay of the tribo charge of the toner based on the difference between two sensor levels, and the charging section charges the toner to a predetermined level based on the calculated decay. The performing section performs a printing operation after the developer is charged.

9. The disclosed methods may

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a rotary magnetic head type apparatus that can control with high precision the recording and reproduction of signals by plural heads. The apparatus is provided with a control signal generator, a decoder circuit, and a current supply circuit to control the bias currents of magneto resistive heads. The control signals are transmitted over a single channel of a rotary transformer and set the operating currents of the magneto resistive heads. The apparatus can independently control each of the bias currents for plural MR heads mounted on a rotary drum.

2. The invention also relates to a recording/reproducing apparatus that permits switching over among plural heads with high precision. The apparatus is provided with a recording/reproducing unit, a generating unit, and a transmitting unit, wherein data for controlling the switching over among the plurality of heads are transmitted with priority over other control data. The apparatus can switch over among plural MR heads and recording heads mounted on a rotary drum at high speed. The bias currents for the MR heads can be controlled with outputs from the one-channel rotary transformer for control signals and the single decoder.

3. The invention further relates to a rotary magnetic head type apparatus that can record and reproduce data at a high speed. The apparatus is provided with plural recording heads and MR heads, and two each of recording or reproducing heads are paired and constitute a double azimuth (DA) structure. The apparatus can record and reproduce data at a speed double that of a conventional apparatus. The bias currents for the MR heads and the recording currents for the recording heads can be regulated independently of one another.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to locating and tracing concealed elongated conductive objects, such as pipes or cables, and improves the ease and accuracy of locating and tracing one object in the presence of an adjacent object.
2. Prior art techniques for locating buried metallic objects include passive and active methods, but these methods can be distorted by the presence of adjacent objects, making it difficult to trace the desired object.
3. The invention uses a transmitter with two antennae to induce distinguishable alternating currents in two adjacent objects, and a receiver that senses the magnetic fields associated with these currents and produces an output signal dependent on both fields.
4. The transmitter is optimally positioned relative to the cables, and the receiver is moved back and forth across the cables to produce an output signal characteristic with two distinct nulls over the respective cables.
5. The invention uses techniques such as different carrier frequencies, amplitude modulation, or pulsing to make the currents in the respective cables distinguishable and produce an output signal dependent on the presence of both currents.
6. The invention is particularly useful in environments where the horizontal separation between cables is related to the depth of the cable to be located and traced, and the effect is enhanced by the fact that the field from the transmitter decreases by the inverse cube of the distance between an antenna and a cable.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to an apparatus for interfacing a speaker phone with a telephone network to permit hands-free automatic answering and communication. The apparatus includes a source of power, selective switch means, and a coupler for automatically coupling the telephone network to the speaker device. The invention also includes a timer for controlling the length of time of the interconnection and a bypass switch for bypassing the timer. The apparatus can be used on or in connection with a private telephone line or switchboard extension.

2. The invention provides a device which can be used by the physically handicapped or for an outpatient during a period of convalescence to respond to an inquiry from trained hospital personnel. Hands-free conversation is also advantageous for persons whose activities make handling a telephone difficult or dangerous, such as those having wet or soiled hands, cooks, hairdressers, automobile mechanics, or those people whose tasks require the use of both hands. The invention provides a simplified, portable, readily connectable, automatic answering service for automatically interconnecting incoming telephone calls with a speaker phone. The device is capable of being moved to various telephone jack locations throughout a particular installation.

3. The invention includes a two-way speaker phone unit and an interfacer device that operates to answer an incoming call automatically and switch the incoming call to the speaker phone unit so that a two-way conversation may proceed. The interfacer device includes a timing means which has the capability of turning off the speaker-phone unit at the end of an adjustable preset interval to terminate the telephone conversation. The device also includes means to override the timing means to extend the call by actuating an extend switch. A light indicator is also provided on the panel of the device to indicate the state of actuation of the extend switch.

4. The invention includes an electronic system which comprises the interfacer device, and an electromechanical system for achieving the features of the invention. The electronic system includes an optocoupler, a timer circuit, and a relay, while the electromechanical system includes a neon lamp, a photocell, and a photocell relay. The invention permits the following modes of operation: regular operation by the telephone network without connection of the speaker phone, automatic connection of the speaker phone permitting hands-free communication, termination of such calls at the end of an adjustable predetermined time, and bypassing the timing circuit to permit extended conversation.

5. The invention provides a modular package capable of being moved to various telephone jack locations throughout a particular installation, thus minimizing the capital expenditure of the user while maximizing the versatility

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to the field of optical fiber communications, specifically system network design and incorporation of branch powered amplification within such networks. The emergence of practical optical fiber amplifiers has led to a significant expansion in undersea lightwave communications systems, with transmission capacities reaching values in excess of 5 Gb/s. New applications of wavelength-division-multiplexing technologies are expected to further increase system capacities.

2. The focus has shifted from expanding point-to-point capacity to developing more reliable undersea lightwave systems that provide multipoint-to-multipoint connectivity. A ring topology is known to enhance a network's survivability in the event of a cable fault, and combining a trunk and branch structure with a ring geometry provides strong survivability features. This allows all nodes to remain connected in the event of a cable cut.

3. The use of trunk and branch structures within a communication system also enhances network survivability, as a cable cut in the branch isolates a single network node only. A network that combines a trunk and branch structure with a ring geometry exhibits strong survivability features, including maintaining connectivity along the entirety of the trunk and branch network. This allows all nodes to remain connected in the event of a cable cut.

4. The present invention reduces the number of undersea optical repeaters required by replacing them with remotely pumped optical amplifiers and remotely supplying energy to those optical amplifiers over the same branch cables that distribute communications signals. This approach eliminates the need for additional optical fiber cable runs and achieves amplification of attenuated signals using solely passive repeaterless components. The invention utilizes the branch fiber optic cable to unidirectionally transmit optical energy at a wavelength other than that of signal wavelength.

5. The invention includes a hub assembly with remote pumping, which consists of a hub coupled to both ends of the optical fiber cable trunk, maintaining ring topology continuity. A light emitting power source is coupled onto the optical fiber cable trunk, either through the hub itself or directly onto the optical fiber cable trunk. The light source is capable of producing light at a wavelength that can be used as an energy source for the intended optical amplifier.

6. The branch assembly includes a cable station, a light emitting power source, and a branching unit, which maintains continuity along the optical fiber cable trunk and allows for insertion of new signals and extraction of existing signals via the branch fiber optic cable. The branching unit is tunable, allowing for system network reconfiguration as cable station processing components are added, deleted, upgraded, or otherwise changed. The

<summary>
1. The invention is a cover plate device for wall-mounted electrical wiring devices that eliminates the need for visible fasteners, providing a finished look and preventing shock hazards, and can be quickly and easily installed or removed using simple tools and available fasteners.
2. The device consists of a two-part design, with an attachment member installed over a wiring device and mounted to it, and a cover plate member that fits over the attachment member, with latching pawls and saw-tooth shaped racks that allow for independent engagement and accommodation of variations in wall flatness or evenness.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a collapsible light-shielding device for a screen, consisting of concentrically nested annular strips that can be fixed in front of a displaying screen and surround it, with the strips being able to slide over each other between a pushed-in position and a pushed-out position.
2. The device allows for easy fitting to a monitor, can be set to various angular positions relative to the screen, and enables viewing from different angles without hindrance, making it an improved extendable shielding device compared to prior art.

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to automated speech technologies, specifically providing an indication to a speaker when their rate of speech is likely to be greater than a rate that a listener can comprehend.
2. The invention aims to solve the problem of native speakers speaking too quickly for non-native listeners to understand, and the listener's reluctance to ask the speaker to slow down.
3. The solution involves determining a speaking rate threshold based on the listener's language proficiency and notifying the speaker to slow down when their speaking rate exceeds the threshold.
4. The invention can be implemented in various forms, including wearable devices, teleprompters, and networked computing devices, and can also consider factors such as speech clarity and network quality.
5. The method can automatically detect the language being spoken, determine the listener's language proficiency, and adjust the speaking rate threshold accordingly, providing a more effective way to facilitate understanding between discourse participants.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a device for optical recording of rapid processes with a TV camera, which allows for high and selectable resolution in time with simple means and flexibility.
2. The device comprises a cyclic line counter, a sawtooth generator, and a beam suppression circuit, which work together to scan a selected number of lines on a picture plane and suppress the beam to achieve a higher picture sequence frequency.
3. The device can be programmed to scan a variable number of lines, allowing for adjustable time resolution and spatial resolution, and can be used to record processes that were previously only possible with expensive film cameras.
4. The recorded video signals can be digitized and stored for analysis, and the device is also suitable for recording IR, UV, or X-ray pictures.

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to multimedia communications, particularly handling multimedia calls with clients having legacy phones and services. It provides a solution in the packet domain for integrating voice calls with multimedia sessions as a blended call.

2. The invention uses a multimedia server associated with a telephony server, where the multimedia server has software that manages blended calls, using the functions of the multimedia server and the telephony server where appropriate. The software is referred to as a blender, which may be a function of sequential logic devices or other hardware.

3. The blender receives an incoming call and initiates two call components: a voice call component and a multimedia call component, which are handled through the telephony server and the multimedia server, respectively. The blender integrates the signaling paths into a single signal path, which is used by the multimedia server to control the bearer paths associated with the call.

4. The invention can be used with a Session Initiation Protocol for Telephones (SIP-T) configuration, which contains information helpful in setting up and tearing down the parallel call components. The communication environment includes a communication network with SIP enabled devices, telephony servers, and multimedia servers.

5. Clients are connected to the communication network by one or more connections, which may be wireless or wirebased, and may use a wideband connection suitable for exchanging large amounts of information quickly. The telephony servers and multimedia servers communicate with each other and other components in the communication network via SIP or SIP-T connections.

6. The blender initiates two parallel components for the call, separates the invite into a call request and a multimedia request, and sends the requests to the respective devices. The blender may include an indication that the component is being passed from the blender and that the telephony server is not to redirect or loop the signal back to avoid infinite loops.

7. The invention can be integrated with an Intelligent Network (IN) such that for basic call disposition handling, the IN triggers and commands are used, and for mid-call activation of multimedia features, the multimedia server provides the requested multimedia services. The invention allows for the provision of multimedia services to clients with legacy phones and services, while minimizing the need for new equipment and infrastructure.

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to content synchronization frameworks using dynamic attributes and file bundles for connected devices. The framework allows devices to perform contextual synchronization over various network topologies, including wired and wireless connections. The central reference point, hosted by a server, processes synchronization requests from connected devices and returns responses including bundles identifying files to satisfy the requests. The framework supports both synchronous and asynchronous interaction between the central reference point and connected devices.

2. The synchronization framework provides flexibility to support content synchronization based on device context, which is expressed by the device to the central reference point as dynamic attributes. These attributes are used to compile bundle information for the requesting client, and the content of the bundle is based on the dynamic attribute information provided. The bundles describe the location and properties of content types, such as executable files, libraries, or data, and package this description in a semantic understood by the client. The framework supports multiple languages and appliance operating systems on a single system server.

3. The present systems and methods employ data compression for responses to support limited bandwidth and limited connection time over dial-up or similar connections. The client device composes a delta list of files in the bundle that are different from local copies available to the client device, and the download priority order of the bundle assigned by the central reference point is retained in the delta list. The client retrieves the files in the ordered delta list from various servers indicated in the bundles, and the files downloaded are also compressed to save download time. In the event of communication connection failure, incomplete bundles are rejected.

4. The present content synchronization frameworks provide for creation of a delta list embodying differences between a client's local copy of a file or data and the central reference point indicated file or data. The creation of this delta list is performed by the client device, making the framework highly scalable as the work is distributed instead of being carried out by one server. The central reference point server does not need to store the state of each client device since the appliance creates and maintains this delta list. The framework also provides for caching of most common server responses to make data synchronization more efficient.

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to methods and systems for allowing a person, such as a finder of a valuable or other object, to communicate with the owner of the valuable or other object. The system provides a timely and anonymous communication channel between the finder and the owner. The owner is provided with specially prepared tags with a unique ID and a reference to a specific website or virtual locale.

2. The owner registers the tag ID and their contact information on a centralized and network accessible database. The owner can then associate the tag ID with their contact information, and the system allows the finder to communicate with the owner without revealing the owner's identity. The system also allows the owner to update their contact information and manage their tags.

3. A finder who has found an object with a tag can access the website or virtual locale and enter the tag ID to initiate communication with the owner. The finder can then send a message to the owner, and the system forwards the message to the owner's real email address without revealing the finder's identity. The owner can respond to the message, and the system forwards the response to the finder's real email address.

4. The system allows the owner to view open cases, which are instances of open lines of communication with finders of their tagged objects. The owner can close a case, which marks it as closed in the database, or communicate with the finder of that case. The system also allows the finder to view open cases and communicate with the owner of the tagged object.

5. The system generates anonymous email addresses for the finder and the owner, which are used to facilitate communication between them. The system checks incoming emails to determine if they are addressed to an anonymized email address, and if so, forwards the email to the corresponding real email address. The system also checks the "From" email address to ensure it matches the email address registered in the case record.

6. The system can be used to facilitate the return of lost or misplaced objects to their rightful owners, and provides a convenient and secure way for finders and owners to communicate with each other. The system can be accessed through a website or virtual locale, and allows users to manage their tags and contact information. The system provides a timely and anonymous communication channel between finders and owners, which helps to increase the chances of recovering lost or misplaced objects.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to electron multipliers, specifically a foil electron multiplier that uses a series of thin foils to multiply electrons in a transmission stage. The foil electron multiplier is designed for use in photomultiplier tubes and particle detectors.

2. The foil electron multiplier has several advantages over conventional electron multipliers, including higher gain per multiplication stage, simplicity of fabrication, lower cost, ability to cover larger areas, and intrinsic rejection of ion feedback. The foil electron multiplier can be used in various applications, including electron spectrometers, mass spectrometers, and photonic detectors.

3. The foil electron multiplier consists of a series of thin foils held by foil holders in an evacuated enclosure, with a voltage applied to each foil to accelerate secondary electrons. The foils are arranged collinearly, and the voltage on each stage can be applied using a resistor divider string or separate power supplies.

4. The gain of the foil electron multiplier is maximized by maximizing the electron transmission through the foil, transmission through the support grid, and secondary electron emission yield. The foil material and thickness are selected to optimize the gain.

5. The foil electron multiplier can be used to detect particles such as electrons, ions, and photons, and can provide position-sensitive information on where an incident particle impacted the first stage of the multiplier. The anode can be made from a scintillator material that converts electron energy to light.

6. The gain of the foil electron multiplier is represented by Equation 2, which takes into account the probability of incident particle transmission, transmission through the support grid, and secondary electron emission yield. The gain can be maximized by optimizing the voltage per stage and foil material.

7. The foil electron multiplier does not experience ion feedback, which is a limitation of conventional electron multipliers. Ions generated at the input surface of a particular stage are accelerated toward the previous stage, but cannot penetrate the foil.

8. The foil dimensions and thickness can vary depending on the application, but a preferred embodiment uses a round 1 cm diameter foil with an areal thickness of 0.2 to 1 μg/cm2. The foil material can be carbon, silver, gold, chromium, or hydrocarbons.

9. The distance between foil stages is minimized to save volume, but must be large enough to withstand the applied voltage. A typical design for high voltage standoff is 1 mm per kV.

10. The foil electron multiplier has been demonstrated using a nominal 0.6 μg/cm2 areal

<summary>

1. The 3-D Phenomenoscope invention allows any motion picture to be viewed with a 3-dimensional effect without requiring special filming or projection equipment. The invention utilizes the Pulfrich effect, which creates a 3-dimensional illusion when lateral motion is detected in a motion picture.

2. The Pulfrich effect is a well-known phenomenon where images that travel through a dark lens take longer to register with the brain than images that pass through a clear lens. This delay creates a disparity between the two images, which the brain interprets as depth information.

3. The 3-D Phenomenoscope invention uses glasses with individually controllable lenses that can be darkened or cleared in real-time based on the motion picture being viewed. The glasses also contain a digital sensor, computer processor, and algorithm to detect lateral motion and control the lenses.

4. The algorithm processes successive frames of the motion picture to identify synchronization events and control the state of the lenses. The lenses can take three different states: clear-clear, clear-darkened, and darkened-clear.

5. The 3-D Phenomenoscope invention can be used with any type of motion picture, including those shot on film or digital technology, and can even be used with older movies. No special equipment is needed for filming or projection.

6. The invention overcomes problems associated with 3-dimensional motion pictures, such as the need for special cameras, projection equipment, and viewer discomfort. The 3-D Phenomenoscope is a more practical and comfortable solution.

7. The Pulfrich effect can be used to create a 3-dimensional illusion for objects moving laterally across the screen, and the 3-D Phenomenoscope invention can detect and enhance this effect. The invention can also be used to create other special effects in motion pictures.

8. The 3-D Phenomenoscope invention has many applications, including use in movie theaters, home entertainment systems, and video games. It can also be used to create immersive experiences for educational or training purposes.

9. The invention is a significant improvement over existing 3-dimensional viewing technologies, offering a more practical, comfortable, and widely applicable solution for creating 3-dimensional effects in motion pictures.

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to the dicing of semiconductor wafers, specifically an apparatus and method for singulating individual die from a wafer using pressure to mechanically separate them. The current method of using a wafer saw to cut along scribe lines is slow, requires maintenance, and can damage die. The invention aims to overcome these limitations by using pressure to cause a "clean break" along the scribe lines.

2. The method of the invention involves forming trenches along the scribe lines on the wafer, applying a photo resist layer, and then etching to form the trenches. The wafer is then back-grinded to reduce its thickness, and a layer of adhesive tape is applied to the back surface. The wafer is then placed on a soft pad, and mechanical pressure is applied to the back surface to cause the wafer to break along the trenches.

3. The apparatus of the invention includes a pad for supporting the wafer, a positioning member to position the wafer on the pad, and a pressure mechanism to apply mechanical pressure to the wafer. The pressure mechanism can apply pressure in the X and Y directions or in a circular motion around the wafer. The invention can be used with wafers of any size and type, and the trenches can be formed using alternative methods such as partial cutting with a wafer saw.

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to a field emission display device having a protection structure that deflects ionic emission gas away from the field emission components to prevent damage. The device includes a cathode, an anode, and a protection structure with at least one reduction plate or electrode. The reduction plate is negatively charged to attract positive nitrogen and oxygen ions, preventing them from contacting the cathode and inducing surging electrical currents.

2. The field emission display device has several advantages over traditional liquid crystal display devices, including higher contrast ratio, larger viewing angle, higher maximum brightness, lower power consumption, and a wider operating temperature range. The device uses colored phosphors to produce its own light, eliminating the need for backlights and filters. The device also does not require large arrays of thin film transistors, reducing manufacturing cost and yield problems.

3. The conventional fabrication process for field emission display devices involves complicated processing steps, including thin film deposition and photolithographic techniques, which increase manufacturing cost. The present invention provides a novel protection structure that can be fabricated using a thick film printing technique, reducing fabrication cost and increasing efficiency. The protection structure includes one or multiple reduction plates or electrodes that are electrically connected to a bias voltage source.

4. The reduction plate or plates are typically provided on the cathode and are electrically connected to a bias voltage source that applies a negative voltage. The negative voltage attracts positive nitrogen and oxygen ions, preventing them from contacting the cathode and inducing surging electrical currents. The reduction plate or plates can be fabricated on the cathode plate at the same time as the cathode strips.

5. The protection structure can be formed in various shapes, including elongated and parallel, or meshwork- or net-shaped configurations. The reduction plates can be fabricated on the cathode plate using photolithography and etching techniques. The protection structure can be electrically connected to a bias voltage source that applies a negative voltage to attract positive nitrogen and oxygen ions.

6. The present invention provides a novel field emission display device with a protection structure that prolongs the lifetime of the device by preventing burnout damage to the field emission elements. The device has several advantages over traditional liquid crystal display devices and can be fabricated using a thick film printing technique, reducing manufacturing cost and increasing efficiency. The protection structure can be formed in various shapes and configurations to suit different device designs.

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to an image sensor with multiple imaging planes, which can overcome the limitations of traditional charge-coupled device (CCD) image sensors.
2. Traditional CCD image sensors are formed on flat, circular semiconductor substrates and can only image in a single plane.
3. The invention provides an image sensor that can record information through an edge surface of the sensor, allowing it to image in multiple planes simultaneously.
4. The image sensor comprises a semiconductor substrate with opposed major surfaces and edges, with an image sensor element formed in the substrate adjacent to one edge.
5. The image sensor element includes a charge collection and transfer means and an image sensing region, and means in the substrate guide charge carriers in the image sensing region toward the charge collection and transfer means.
6. In one embodiment, the image sensor includes an elongated substrate with imaging planes on the top surface and two edge surfaces, with three columns of image sensor elements formed in the substrate.
7. The image sensor elements include photodiodes and buried-channel CCDs, and P+ layers are formed in the top surface of the image sensor to guide charge carriers toward the CCDs.
8. The image sensor can be used in various applications, including simultaneous imaging of multiple planes, color applications, and document scanning.
9. The invention can be formed using processing techniques compatible with those used in forming other types of image sensors, making it easily incorporable into various image sensor designs.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to home networks employing devices with power management systems, aiming to minimize total power consumption while ensuring optimal network administration.
2. A network master node performs network administrative functions, such as beacon transmission, device association, and bandwidth assignment, in addition to its nominal device functions.
3. The invention provides methods for transferring network administrative functions from a master device to a slave device, enabling the master device to enter a power management state.
4. A network slave node can accept the transfer of network administrative functions and become the new master node, ensuring continuous network administration.
5. The selection of a new master node can be based on criteria such as visibility, intelligence, or functional capabilities of the slave nodes, or user selection.
6. The transfer of network administrative functions can occur while the slave node is performing its nominal device functions, intermittently with its nominal device functions, or after completing its nominal device functions.
7. The invention enables devices to self-promote to the master node role if no master node is present on the network, ensuring that the network remains operational.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to an antenna array for measuring the direction of propagation of electromagnetic radiation, particularly at low elevation angles. The prior art uses a single equi-spaced triplet arrangement of similar antenna elements, which has limitations in terms of ambiguity and sensitivity. The invention extends this idea to optimize angle measurements using multiple triplets. The triplets are spaced so as to provide at least two equi-spaced linear triplets perpendicular to a ground plane.

2. The antenna array comprises at least four antennae, with each triplet characterized by the spacing of its elements and the height of the centre element above the ground plane. Radio receiver means obtain information signals from each antenna, which are then combined vectorially to provide a first derived signal and a second derived signal. The quotient of these signals is a function of the elevation angle but not of the ground reflection coefficient. The array can operate in receive or transmit mode, with the latter requiring coded transmissions to enable angle measurement.

3. The invention has various applications, including monitoring the height of aircraft approaching to land, which has not been easily achieved with standard secondary surveillance radar systems. The antenna array can be used in conjunction with a directional secondary surveillance radar interrogator to measure the range and elevation angle of identified aircraft. The system can also be used to provide coding of angles in space by radio transmissions. The invention offers improved accuracy and resolution in measuring elevation angles, particularly at low angles.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a seal supported subminiature lamp assembly that provides a liquid tight seal and overcomes the problems of conventional subminiature lamps, such as adhesive breakdown, thermal cycling, and moisture migration. The assembly features a polymeric seal support that directly surrounds and is in compression contact with the glass envelope, and extends downward into contact with the abbreviated height one piece conductive base. The polymeric seal support is made of a material that can withstand high temperatures and has excellent resistance to aggressive fuels and chemicals.

2. The seal supported subminiature lamp assembly has several advantages over conventional lamps, including a longer seal length, elimination of adhesive, and a single surface required to make a seal. The assembly also minimizes the number of sealing points and maximizes the length of the seal surface, reducing the risk of liquid entry and corrosion. The invention can be applied to any situation where insulation, high heat degradation resistance, solvent and chemical resistance is required.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a method for configuring a Generalized Decision Feedback Equalizer (GDFE) precoder in a multi-user multiple-input multiple-output (MU-MIMO) wireless system, which reduces computational cost while achieving no capacity loss. The GDFE precoder is suitable for improving the performance of various MU-MIMO wireless systems, including future "4G" cellular networks.

2. The system model and notations used in the invention include the base station (BS) having N antennas and K user terminals (UTs) with Lk antennas each, where L is the sum of antennas at UTs. The combined channel gain matrix between the BS and the K UTs is denoted by H, and the input symbol vector destined for the kth UT is denoted by uk.

3. The GDFE precoder includes an interference pre-cancellation block denoted by I-G, where G has the structure of a Block Upper Right Triangular matrix, and the transmit filter B is used to process the symbol vector x obtained after the DFE stage. The feedforward filter F is related to the interference pre-cancellation matrix G by a novel expression.

4. The input covariance matrix Sxx for the downlink channel is defined as Sxx = E[xxH] and satisfies the transmit power constraint, and the transmit filter B is denoted by B = VΣ1/2M, where M is a unitary matrix and the matrices {V, Σ} are same as defined in the Eigen Value Decomposition (EVD) of Sxx.

5. The invention provides alternative methods to compute the filter matrix C, which is used to compute the matrices B, G, and F, without the knowledge of the "Least Favorable Noise" covariance matrix Szz. These methods include using the QR decomposition of C, and solving a limit equation to determine C.

6. Numerical examples are provided to illustrate the computation of various matrices involved in the design of GDFE Precoder, including the computation of the optimal input covariance matrix Sxx for the downlink channel, and the "Least Favorable Noise" covariance matrix Szz.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a heat-dissipating device and a housing thereof, which aims to increase the intake airflow rate without modifying the assembling conditions with other elements. The device is designed to greatly enhance the heat-dissipating performance of the fan.

2. A typical electrical product includes electrical elements positioned in a closed housing to prevent contamination with particles in the air. However, the electrical element tends to be consumed and its lifetime tends to be shortened if it is continuously kept at a high-temperature condition.

3. A conventional fan is composed of a fan housing and an impeller, which produces air streams to dissipate heat generated from the electrical element. The fan housing includes an air inlet and an air outlet in communication with the air inlet via a central, cylindrical air passage.

4. The conventional fan has limitations in its design, including a restricted air passage at the lateral side, optimized design of the blade shape, and wasted space and material of the fan housing. Additionally, air can only be taken into the fan in the axial direction, which limits the improvement in intake airflow rate.

5. The invention provides a heat-dissipating fan and a housing thereof, where an sidewall of the housing extends outwards to enlarge the intake airflow area without modifying the assembling conditions with other elements. The shape of the housing at the air outlet side is kept unchanged to enhance the heat-dissipating efficiency of the fan.

6. The invention also provides a heat-dissipating device and a housing thereof, where an sidewall of the housing extends outwards to enlarge its intake airflow area, allowing the impeller to increase its dimension and airflow rate. This enhances the heat-dissipating efficiency of the fan.

7. The air passage formed by the sidewall of the housing reduces gradually and evenly in its cross-sectional area, effectively concentrating air streams to the center and enhancing heat-dissipating efficiency. The air streams can then blow to the center portion of the heat sink having the highest temperature.

8. The housing includes an outer frame having a passage for guiding air streams to flow from an opening to another opening, where an sidewall of the passage of one of the opening sides extends radially outwards. The sidewall of the passage extends radially outwardly with respect to a central axis of the passage in a symmetrical manner.

9. The heat-dissipating device includes an impeller and a housing for receiving the impeller, where the housing includes a passage for guiding air streams to

<summary>
1. The electroluminescent display panel of the present invention is able to display different colors according to the situations without using an intermediate electrode, and images are able to be selectively displayed in a color including no visible red components or in a color including visible red components with a high luminance.
2. The display panel is composed of various layers laminated on a glass substrate, including a first electrode layer, a first insulation layer, a first luminescent layer, a second luminescent layer, a second insulation layer, and a second electrode layer, which are designed to change the display color by changing the driving voltage.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a portable communications terminal for Internet/network telephony, which uses a network and/or the Internet for transferring information/data representing digitized speech, sounds, music, etc. The terminal establishes a wireless connection to a connecting unit, which establishes a connection to a network and/or the Internet, and the terminal can independently control and communicate data packets according to a standardized Internet/network protocol.

2. The system according to the invention comprises a service server connected to the Internet and/or a network, which keeps track of which terminals/users are accessible and where, and provides additional services, functions, etc., such as news, reading of mails, speech mails, commercials, music, stock exchange and financial news, etc. The server can also establish connections between users who want to communicate with each other, and provide functionalities like chat-lines, chat-rooms, telephone meetings, etc.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to the integration of high-dielectric oxide materials with semiconductor substrates, particularly silicon and gallium arsenide. The integration is challenging due to the reactivity of silicon with oxygen, leading to the formation of a low-dielectric constant layer. This layer degrades the properties of the high-dielectric oxide material.

2. High-dielectric oxide materials, such as ferroelectrics, have advantages like ferroelectric properties, size reduction of capacitors, and electrooptic applications. Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric materials are convenient due to their low annealing temperatures, but they are reactive and diffuse into metals. These materials are not thermodynamically stable next to silicon or gallium arsenide.

3. The integration of non-SiO2 based oxides directly or indirectly on silicon is difficult due to the strong reactivity of silicon with oxygen. The deposition of non-SiO2 oxides generally results in the formation of a SiO2 or silicate layer at the Si/oxide interface. This layer is amorphous and has a low dielectric constant.

4. Ferroelectrics with a large dielectric constant can be used to form high-density capacitors, but they cannot be deposited directly on silicon due to the reaction of silicon to form a low-dielectric constant layer. Such capacitor dielectrics have been deposited on "inert" metals like platinum, but even platinum or palladium must be separated from silicon with one or more conductive buffer layers. The high dielectric material on a conductive layer has not solved the problem.

5. The large spontaneous polarization of ferroelectrics can be used to form a non-volatile, non-destructive readout, field-effect memory. This has been successfully done with non-oxide ferroelectrics, but much less successfully with oxide ferroelectrics due to the formation of the low-dielectric constant SiO2 layer. The oxide can also poison the silicon device or create interface traps.

6. Ferroelectrics have interesting electrooptic applications where epitaxial films are preferred to reduce loss due to scattering from grain boundaries and to align the oxide to maximize its anisotropic properties. The epitaxial growth on silicon or gallium arsenide substrates has previously been accomplished by first growing a very stable oxide or fluoride on the substrate as a buffer layer.

7. A germanium buffer layer on silicon oxidizes much less readily and can be used to prevent or minimize the formation of

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a receiver input circuit that enables substantial elimination of undesired signal actuation of non-linear components in the signal path, resulting in distortions, while taking into account adequate small signal behavior and using conventional components.
2. The circuit achieves this through the use of multiple amplification control loops with different response thresholds and frequency bandwidths, which work together to prevent overloading of the mixer stage and varactor diodes, and to reduce signal distortions and interference.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to network-implemented shared workspace environments, specifically an apparatus and method for setting up a collaborative work-sharing environment between physically distant individuals. This environment allows for spontaneous collaboration, reducing the need for complex and time-consuming setup processes.

2. Current collaborative work-share environments include video conferencing, document sharing, and shared "whiteboard" systems, but these systems are often expensive and require dedicated equipment. PC-based products, such as Intel's ProShare and Microsoft's NetMeeting, are more economical and can be deployed on every networked PC.

3. However, these PC-based products are difficult to use, especially for those without technical backgrounds, and require cumbersome setup processes, including establishing IP addresses and launching software. The setup process often requires a separate phone call to coordinate.

4. The present invention provides a system for initiating a collaborative work-share environment between two or more parties to a telephone call, without complex and time-consuming setup processes. The system uses a collaboration button and indicator on each telephone set to signal the availability of network collaboration.

5. When the indicator is illuminated, the system can establish a work-share environment, allowing parties to share information, conduct video conferences, and maintain their initial voice connection. The telephone is used in the usual way to make regular voice-only calls.

6. The collaboration control program runs on each PC associated with a telephone and communicates with the phone to control the collaborate indicator and sense actuation of the collaborate button. The program also communicates with remote PCs to determine whether mutual collaboration application programs can inter-operate.

7. The system can be implemented in various architectures, including peer-to-peer and client-server, and can be used for multiparty collaboration with minor modifications. The invention can also be applied to systems using dedicated telephone transport, such as PBX, PSTN, or ISDN.

8. The present invention can be implemented by remote computers connected over a network, and the telephone equipment can be integrated within the computer, with the indicator and collaborative button provided by an input device of the computer.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a method and device for inserting advertising clips into a video sequence, taking into account the regions of interest of the video sequence and the advertising clips to ensure a continuity of salience between the two.
2. The method involves generating salience maps for the video sequence and the advertising clips, determining a degree of similarity between the maps, selecting the clip with the highest degree of similarity, and inserting it into the video sequence at a point, such as a shot change, to optimize the visual impact of the advertising.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to the use of a recessed mask structure to prevent localized high electrical fields at intersections in very small dimension semiconductor devices, resulting in lower electrical breakdown. This is particularly useful in high speed and high density integrated circuit applications and chip interconnect structures with fine metal features and low dielectric constant insulators.

2. In miniaturizing semiconductor devices, dimensional tolerances become very small, and abrupt physical discontinuities produce high electrical fields, resulting in enhanced leakage and breakdown. Different materials with different properties are being used, which behave differently in processing and require new solutions.

3. The invention provides a metal plus low dielectric constant interconnect structure for a semiconductor device, where a differentiating or mask member is positioned below a surface to be planarized, at a location where the surfaces of the regions separated by the dielectric are undisturbed and have complete integrity. The mask position is in the range of about 0.5 to 20 nanometers, with 5 nanometers being preferred, below the surface to be planarized.

4. The invention is particularly useful in damascene type device structures, where adjacent conductors lined with an electrically conductive and diffusion barrier film are disposed in thin trenches in an intralevel dielectric material. Connections are made to levels above and below through metal filled vias in the ILD, and masking is employed both to protect the dielectric material between conductors during processing operations and to assist in patterning those trenches within the interlevel dielectric material.

5. The recessed mask structure is achieved through a unique process that permits both the benefit of having a recessed surface of the mask with respect to a device surface where there may be aspects to avoid, such as high electric field concentration points, and the benefit of having a final mask thickness that is selectable and no thicker than necessary. The process involves removing mask material between points of high electric field concentration after chemical-mechanical polishing, down to a level that is away from the surface where the high fields are located.

6. The invention provides several beneficial features, including the high field points being away from the cap-mask interface, minimizing damage to the conductive liner, and providing a lower and predictable overall capacitance, which results in faster signal propagation in the interconnect wiring. The structure of the invention, when integrated into a component, has a lower capacitance than prior art structures.

<summary>
1. The Downconverting Digitizer invention utilizes predictive coding principles to implement a simple downconverting A/D converter, eliminating the complexities introduced by discrete-time analog circuitry.
2. The invention achieves three processes: conversion of the modulated IF signal to a digital representation, downconversion of the modulated IF signal to a digital representation of the baseband in-phase and quadrature components, and automatic control of the processed modulated IF signal amplitude to extend the dynamic range of the digitization process.
3. The predictive filter element plays a central role in the operation of this invention, generating a prediction of the modulated IF at the next sampling epoch, and filtering out quantization noise while increasing the word length of the digital representation of the signal.
4. The invention offers several advantages, including the ability to dynamically adjust the frequency response of the predictive digital filter, word length expansion, and improved dynamic range and detection bandwidth, making it suitable for various applications such as cellular telephony.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to active solid-state devices, specifically to apparatus and methods for making and using sensors with nanodimensional features that are responsive to molecular compounds, organisms, or gas molecules.
2. The use of nanowires and nanotubes for label-free direct real-time detection of biomolecule binding is known in the art, and the depletion or accumulation of charge carriers caused by binding can affect the entire cross-sectional conduction pathway of these nanostructures.
3. Nanoimprint lithography (NIL) is a method that can pattern nano-scale features into a quartz plate, which can be applied directly to the surface of a wafer and transfer the pattern into a photoresist layer.
4. The invention provides a cost-effective, time-efficient, and reproducible method for fabricating arrays of nano-scale features on a single wafer to form a sensor device or a matrix of devices for multiplex detection of selected analytes.
5. Each sensor device consists of a set of two interdigitated electrodes, including a source electrode and a drain electrode, and a set of parallel semiconductor nanotraces that are perpendicular to and disposed across the interdigitated finger region of the electrodes.
6. The semiconductor nanotraces are fabricated using nanoimprint lithography and have a width of 10 nm to 100 nm and a length that spans the full distance from the outside source interdigitated finger to the outside drain interdigitated finger of each sensor device.
7. The response of the sensor device is proportional to the degree in which the electrical current traversing the set of semiconductor nanotraces is influenced by changes in the electric field strength near the surface of each nanotrace.
8. The fabrication of a set of parallel nanotraces serves to homogenize the total response to changes in the local environment, lowering the failure rate of sensor devices during fabrication of the multiplex detection array.

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a method of singulating and plating semiconductor packages, employing plating of the side surfaces of the leads of the leadframe to prevent contamination of the lead surfaces.
2. The method involves providing a plurality of semiconductor dies coupled to a single common leadframe, singulating the plurality of semiconductor dies, and plating the exposed side surfaces of the leads with a plating material.
3. The plating material is preferably a material configured not to react with oxygen, such as tin, silver, gold, nickel-gold, nickel-palladium, or nickel-palladium-gold.
4. The singulation process can be performed using full cutting or partial cutting, with the latter involving multiple cutting operations to complete the singulation of the semiconductor packages.
5. The side surfaces of the semiconductor packages can be configured in different shapes, such as straight or beveled, depending on the cutting process used.
6. The finished individual semiconductor packages have a semiconductor die and a leadframe at least partially encased in a molding compound, with the leads of each leadframe being accessible to electrical coupling via the plating material over the portions of the leads that are exposed from the molding compound.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a dual mode mobile terminal that can selectively connect to a wireless wide area network (WWAN) and a wireless local area network (WLAN), and a method for switching between these two networks.
2. The mobile terminal has two network modules, a GSM module for connecting to the WWAN and a WiFi module for connecting to the WLAN, and can switch between the two networks based on signal strength and other factors.
3. The WLAN access point has a GSM module that gathers service information from neighboring base stations, which is then transmitted to the mobile terminal to facilitate a faster connection to the WWAN when needed.
4. The invention allows for a seamless handover from the WLAN to the WWAN, reducing the likelihood of dropped connections and improving overall communication quality.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to the production of multilayered components, particularly multilayer capacitors, and provides a new process and apparatus to simplify the manufacturing process. The conventional process involves seven steps, including casting, printing, stacking, cutting, thermal processing, metallizing, and testing.

2. The new process eliminates steps 4 and 6, which are the most labor-intensive and costly, and instead uses decals to form electrode and electrical component composites. The decals are then stacked and fired to form the final product.

3. The process involves preparing decals with electrodes and electrical components, which are then stacked and fired to form the final product. The electrodes and components are formed using a screening process, and the decals are guided into precise registration using guide posts.

4. The invention allows for the production of multilayer capacitors with a wide range of sizes and configurations, including small sizes and complex electrode configurations. The process also enables the production of capacitors with lower voltage ratings and without shape limitations.

5. The new process has several advantages, including the elimination of cutting stress cracks, internal delamination, and labor-intensive steps. It also enables in-process inspection, rapid response to customer demand, and the provision of a variety of tab configurations.

6. The invention is not limited to the production of multilayer capacitors, but can also be used to produce other electronic ceramic devices, such as multilayer ferrite inductors, substrates with buried metal circuitry, semiconductor packages, and precision registers. The process can be used to fabricate a wide range of devices with complex configurations and structures.

<summary>

1. The invention relates to cellular materials used in structural applications, specifically to materials comprising hierarchical cellular lattices and related methods of using and manufacturing the same. The lattice structures have improved specific stiffness and strength while maintaining a low weight.
